"What happens when a piece of zinc is placed in a solution of copper sulfate? Write the balanced chemical equation for the reaction, identify the type of reaction, and predict which elements will be oxidized and which will be reduced."
message_2:
When a piece of zinc is placed in a solution of copper sulfate, a single displacement (redox) reaction occurs. Zinc replaces copper in the copper sulfate solution, forming zinc sulfate and copper metal. The balanced chemical equation for this reaction is:

Zn (s) + CuSO₄ (aq) → ZnSO₄ (aq) + Cu (s)

In this reaction, zinc is oxidized, meaning it loses electrons, while copper is reduced, meaning it gains electrons. The oxidation and reduction half-reactions are as follows:

Oxidation half-reaction: Zn (s) → Zn²⁺ (aq) + 2e⁻
Reduction half-reaction: Cu²⁺ (aq) + 2e⁻ → Cu (s)

So, in summary, when zinc is placed in a copper sulfate solution, a single displacement reaction occurs, forming zinc sulfate and copper metal. Zinc is oxidized, and copper is reduced.
